author: By Jill Cowan
title: California Set to Extend Eviction Protections
description: Monday: Here’s what to know about the deal aimed at preventing California from falling off an “eviction cliff.”
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saif Hasnat
title: Migrant workers flee Bangladesh’s capital ahead of a new lockdown.
description: Much of the public transportation system is already closing or closed, with new measures to control the spread of the virus scheduled to come fully into force on Thursday.
content: Bangladesh will return to national lockdown by the end of the week, responding to a wave of infections that on Monday brought its highest single-day death toll of the pandemic so far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Boeing faces new questions on the development of its latest big plane.
description: The Federal Aviation Administration says the 777X may need more test flights and will get closer scrutiny, adding to the manufacturer’s recent troubles.
content: Boeing has suffered a setback in its effort to win regulatory approval for the 777X, a large jet designed for long-range flights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai and Dan Bilefsky
title: At Nearly 116 Degrees, Heat in Western Canada Shatters National Record
description: The heat is expected to continue for several days in some parts of British Columbia, according to weather warnings from the government.
content: TORONTO — Vancouverites were frying eggs on pans placed on their terraces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: The Mike Pence Saga Tells Us More Than We Want to Know
description: But he is not the only politician who shows which way the wind is blowing.
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I was hoping to pick up where we left off last week, with the New York City mayoral primary and our new ranked-choice voting system. Assuming Eric Adams holds on to his lead, what do you think his win says about the state of the city — and of the Democratic Party?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: It’s Some of America’s Richest Farmland. But What Is It Without Water?
description: A California farmer decides it makes better business sense to sell his water than to grow rice. An almond farmer considers uprooting his trees to put up solar panels. Drought is transforming the state, with broad consequences for the food supply.
content: ORDBEND, Calif. — In America’s fruit and nut basket, water is now the most precious crop of all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley, Vivian Wang and Austin Ramzy
title: Crossing the Red Line: Behind China’s Takeover of Hong Kong
description: One year ago, the city’s freedoms were curtailed with breathtaking speed. But the clampdown was years in the making, and many signals were missed.
content: Hong Kong’s march toward an authoritarian future began with a single phrase in a dry policy paper. Beijing, the document declared, would wield “comprehensive jurisdiction” over the territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: Marco Gobbetti, Burberry’s chief executive, quits to join Ferragamo.
description: Shares fell 8 percent on news that Mr. Gobbetti, who joined in 2017 with a goal to take Burberry further upmarket, was leaving.
content: Marco Gobbetti, who was tasked with turning Burberry into more of an upmarket luxury brand when he was appointed chief executive in 2017, is quitting after five years in the role.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: June 28, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, June 28, 2021.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Acts in Cases on Transgender Rights and Excessive Force
description: In both cases, some of the most conservative justices signaled frustration with the court’s cautious approach to divisive issues.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday let stand a transgender youth’s victory in a case on access to high school bathrooms and revived a lawsuit from the parents of a man who had died in police custody.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna P. Kambhampaty
title: Skims Is the Official Underwear of the U.S. Olympic Team
description: Kim Kardashian West’s shapewear company will also be providing loungewear and sleepwear for Team U.S.A.
content: Kim Kardashian West’s shapewear brand, Skims, will provide the official underwear, loungewear and pajamas for female American athletes at the Tokyo Olympic and Paralympic Games this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon
title: Vaccines, Facebook, Miami: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Sydney Outbreak Tied to Delta Variant Grows
description: Naked sunbathers fleeing deer were among 44 people fined for violating stay-at-home orders.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — Australia faced a grim and anxiety-inducing challenge on Monday: simultaneous outbreaks of the coronavirus in several parts of the country, most notably in Sydney, fueled by the spread of the highly infectious Delta variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: House Passes Bills to Bolster Scientific Research, Breaking With Senate
description: The legislation would invest in traditional research and development, clashing with a broad Senate measure that focuses on cutting-edge technology to compete with China.
content: WASHINGTON — The House on Monday passed two bipartisan bills aimed at bolstering research and development programs in the United States, setting up a battle with the Senate over how best to invest in scientific innovation to strengthen American competitiveness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: The United Auto Workers name a successor to the departing president.
description: The union chose its secretary-treasurer, Ray Currie, for the top job until an election next June.
content: The United Auto Workers on Monday chose a key finance official to take over as the union’s president until the next scheduled leadership election in June 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Farber
title: Lydia Lunch’s Infinite Rebellion
description: “Good luck figuring me out,” the 62-year-old artist said. A new documentary called “The War Is Never Over” does its best.
content: For nearly two hours on a recent afternoon, Lydia Lunch sat in her bright Brooklyn apartment and spoke with bracing speed, and at an alarming volume, about rape, murder, incest, genocide, racism, sadism, torture and — for a thunderous encore — the apocalypse. Because she has spent more than four decades broadcasting her belief that such brutal subjects lie at the heart of the human experience, critics have often cast her as a nihilist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: Penthouse at Troubled Supertall Tower Seeks $169 Million
description: The 96th floor apartment at 432 Park Avenue, where residents complained of construction defects, is asking more than $20,500 a square foot.
content: The 96th-floor penthouse at 432 Park Avenue, the nearly 1,400-foot supertall tower on Manhattan’s Billionaires Row, where residents complained of a number of mechanical issues earlier this year, is listing for $169 million, one of the most ambitious listings in the country since the start of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: A Spectator’s Sign Felled Dozens of Tour de France Racers
description: The French authorities were searching for a woman who they said left the scene after a German cyclist crashed into her sign, setting off a pileup during the first stage of the race.
content: The French authorities said they were looking for an unidentified woman who held a banner along the side of the road at the Tour de France on Saturday, leading to a collision that sent dozens of cyclists tumbling to the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: An Unmarried Catholic Schoolteacher Got Pregnant. She Was Fired.
description: A lawsuit that she filed in New Jersey is testing the First Amendment limits of religious freedom.
content: When a Catholic school art teacher was asked to take on extra responsibilities, she requested a raise, explaining that she was about to have a baby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Campus in Hungary is Flagship of Orban’s Bid to Create a Conservative Elite
description: A residential college was granted about $1.7 billion by Prime Minister Viktor Orban, part of his plan to create a more nationalistic society. Critics say it is legalized theft of public funds.
content: BUDAPEST — On a leafy hilltop in Budapest, a small educational foundation inside an aging, former Communist police building has audacious plans to train a conservative future elite. It is constructing a colossal campus, wooing conservative intellectuals for the faculty and expanding its programs to train 10,000 students across Hungary and elsewhere in Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: New York and New Jersey Need an $11B Tunnel. Will Biden Make It Happen?
description: The transportation secretary said building a new rail link under the Hudson River is critical to the economy far beyond the region.
content: Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg got a close-up look at the crumbling state of New York City’s most critical rail link on Monday and vowed that the Biden administration was committed to getting a new train tunnel built under the Hudson River.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Sydney McLaughlin sets a world record in the 400-meter hurdles.
description: In one of the most anticipated finals of the trials, Sydney McLaughlin outsprinted Dalilah Muhammad to win the women’s 400-meter hurdles.
content: In one of the most anticipated finals of the trials, Sydney McLaughlin outsprinted Dalilah Muhammad to win the women’s 400-meter hurdles — and break Muhammad’s world record. McLaughlin finished in 51.90 seconds, becoming the first woman to run the race in less than 52 seconds. She looked up at the clock and put her hands over her mouth in shock as Muhammad ran to her to celebrate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The People vs. Agent Orange’ and Macy’s Fireworks
description: PBS airs a documentary about the enduring effects of Agent Orange. And the Macy’s annual fireworks display returns to New York in full force.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, June 28-July 4. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Danielle Lao Gets Back to Wimbledon, and Makes the Most of It
description: Lao still lives at home in California with her parents to save money, but will be on Court 17 on Monday after qualifying for the Grand Slam tournament for the first time at age 30.
content: When Danielle Lao made her first visit to Wimbledon in 2019, she tried to describe it to her parents Bessie and Danny.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court revives a case on excessive force by the police.
description: The justices ordered an appeals court to take a fresh look at whether St. Louis police officers may be sued over the death of man held down in a police station.
content: The Supreme Court ordered an appeals court to take another look at a ruling in favor of police officers accused of using excessive force in pressing on the back of a man who was facedown on the ground, suffocating him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Harry Potter and the Cursed Child’ to Slim Down Before Broadway Return
description: Reducio! The play, which had been performed in two parts, will be condensed and restaged in one part when it returns this fall.
content: “Harry Potter and the Cursed Child,” the sprawling stage play that imagines Harry and his friends as grown-ups and their children as wizards-in-training, will be substantially restructured before returning to Broadway this fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: The BET Awards Gave Us a Lot to Process
description: Red-carpet stunners, a surprise make-out session, the reveal of Cardi B’s second pregnancy and so much more.
content: Given everything that happened at Sunday’s BET Awards, one would be forgiven for needing some time to process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Emily Schmall, Suhasini Raj and Hari Kumar
title: The Night the Oxygen Ran Out
description: A cascading series of failures, from the central government on down, left hospitals across India without medical oxygen, killing hundreds. One tragic night in Delhi shows how it happened.
content: NEW DELHI — At 9:45 p.m., alarms blared across the intensive care unit of Jaipur Golden Hospital. Over two dozen patients on ventilators couldn’t breathe. Some flailed their arms and legs. Others cried for help, choking sounds coming from their throats as if they were being strangled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: ‘I’m Easily Bored by Books,’ Says Writer of 22 Novels
description: The latest from the aptly named Francine Prose is “The Vixen,” a surprisingly funny tale involving Ethel Rosenberg and the C.I.A.
content: Francine Prose writes a lot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: The Coach Wanted the Job. His Agent Wanted More.
description: Gennaro Gattuso’s 23-day tenure as Fiorentina manager was marked by disagreements about player signings and the unusual influence of the superagent Jorge Mendes.
content: Rocco Commisso was hoping this appointment would be the one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: An Accusation Blew Up a Campaign. The Media Didn’t Know What to Do.
description: Handling a delicate allegation of sexual misconduct is a lot more challenging than covering a horse race.
content: Two days after coming in fifth in the election night count of votes for New York mayor last week, Scott Stringer was sitting in a high-polish diner in TriBeCa, drinking his second bottle of Sprite and trying to figure out what had happened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: Obamacare’s Survival Is Now Assured, but It Still Has One Big Problem
description: Twelve states have refused to expand Medicaid, leaving millions of poor Americans without health coverage and Democrats divided over how to respond.
content: Some Democrats are eager to build on their Affordable Care Act victories in the Supreme Court by filling a gaping hole created along the way: the lack of Medicaid coverage for millions of low-income Americans in 12 states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Facebook Goes Boring. Yes!
description: Bringing the rest of the world online requires a million different tactics, and Facebook is on it.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: Judge Throws Out 2 Antitrust Cases Against Facebook
description: The decisions were a major blow to attempts to rein in Big Tech. The judge said one of the complaints, from the Federal Trade Commission, lacked facts and gave the agency 30 days to refile it.
content: WASHINGTON — In a stunning setback to regulators’ efforts to break up Facebook, a federal judge on Monday threw out antitrust lawsuits brought against the company by the Federal Trade Commission and more than 40 states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Right Goes All In on Ignorance
description: Why Tucker Carlson called General Milley a pig.
content: As everyone knows, leftists hate America’s military. Recently, a prominent left-wing media figure attacked Gen. Mark Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, declaring, “He’s not just a pig, he’s stupid.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Pfizer and Moderna Vaccines Likely to Produce Lasting Immunity, Study Finds
description: Immune cells are still organizing to fight the coronavirus months after inoculation, scientists reported.
content: The vaccines made by Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna set off a persistent immune reaction in the body that may protect against the coronavirus for years, scientists reported on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: France Falls and Spain Survives as Euro 2020 Comes Alive
description: Spain was cruising against Croatia, until suddenly it wasn’t. France was out, then back in, then out for good after a penalty shootout against Switzerland.
content: It would be too definitive to declare that Monday, June 28, 2021 was the greatest day of tournament soccer in history. Over the last 90 years, after all, there will have been days that have brought an even grander torrent of jaw-dropping drama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Stacey Cowley and Alan Rappeport
title: Biden’s effort to center racial equity in policymaking is hitting roadblocks.
description: Since taking office 157 days ago, President Biden has promised to put racial equity at the center of everything he does, pledging in an executive order on Day 1 to take a “systematic approach to embedding fairness in decision-making” as he drafts legislation, hires staff, proposes spending and develops regulations.
content: Since taking office 157 days ago, President Biden has promised to put racial equity at the center of everything he does, pledging in an executive order on Day 1 to take a “systematic approach to embedding fairness in decision-making” as he drafts legislation, hires staff, proposes spending and develops regulations.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What the Japanese Think of the Olympics
description: Despite low coronavirus vaccination rates and an ambivalent public, Tokyo is still set to host the Games.
content: The 2020 Olympics in Tokyo were supposed to be a symbol of recovery — a signal to the world that, after a huge earthquake in 2011, Japan had bounced back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Translucent History of Wine
description: The Corning Museum of Glass in western New York features a new exhibition on wine.
content: If your summer road trip takes you to New York’s Southern Tier, along the border with Pennsylvania, or to the Finger Lakes wine country, plan a stop in Corning, the city known for glassware and home of the vast collection in its Museum of Glass. Starting Saturday and running through the end of the year there’s a new exhibit that explores the connection between glass and wine, from ancient Rome to the present. A sealed bottle of wine from an 18th century shipwreck and an elaborate glass wine jug cut in a Russian pattern are among the objects on display.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Introduction to ‘Film Club’
description: Want to learn more about this feature? Watch this introduction video to start engaging students with short nonfiction films.
content: Every week of the school year, we feature a short documentary film published in The New York Times. These films ask students to consider a variety of themes like ethics, civil rights, gender identity and scientific discovery. Each Film Club entry begins with an essential question to help frame the lesson, followed by a set of questions to help students connect the film to their own lives. This feature help students develop visual literacy skills and gives teachers another way to approach important issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel and Jeré Longman
title: The Clock Ticks on Caster Semenya’s Olympic Career
description: Whether or not she qualifies for the Tokyo Games, the South African runner will have provoked an important debate about who should compete in women’s sports.
content: JOHANNESBURG — An Olympic race of sorts ends on Tuesday, and this time Caster Semenya will not reach the finish line first.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Introduction to ‘News Quiz’
description: Want to learn more about this feature? Watch this short introduction video to start testing your current events knowledge.
content: Every week of the school year, we publish a 10-question interactive quiz to challenge students’ knowledge of the week’s biggest news stories. The quiz invites students to select the missing words or phrases from selections of recent New York Times stories. It also challenges students to discern between real and fake headlines, and to match a mystery photo with the news story it depicts. Practicing with our weekly news quizzes can help students keep up with the news and get in the habit of following current events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: An Everyday Upgrade to Your Dinner Table
description: Bklyn Clay has added a pop of color to its dinnerware line.
content: Bklyn Clay, a ceramics studio that offers classes and sells ceramics and materials for potters, has introduced a line of practical stoneware bowls and plates in several sizes. The collection, initially offered in white, now includes satin or glossy finishes, speckled or not, in a range of colors, including celadon, saddle, saffron and a shade of royal blue called cosmo. The plates can be used as covers for the bowls and the pieces are safe in the dishwasher or microwave. Though they’re suitable for everyday use, the price suggests the special occasion category at $40 to $60 per piece, with five-piece dinnerware sets ranging from $255 to $1,020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amit Paley
title: Carl Nassib Came Out. Coaches and Teammates Need to Step Up.
description: Allies have a big role to play in making L.G.B.T.Q. youth feel safe enough to play sports.
content: Last week, Las Vegas Raiders defensive lineman Carl Nassib made the barrier-breaking decision to publicly come out as gay, becoming the first active player in the N.F.L. to do so. Nassib’s news came just days after 21-year-old runner Sha’Carri Richardson thanked her girlfriend after qualifying for the U.S. Olympic team. And just two days later, Kumi Yokoyama, a forward for the Washington Spirit women’s soccer team, came out as a transgender man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum, Ben Protess and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Trump’s Lawyers Make Late Bid to Fend Off Charges Against His Business
description: An indictment against the business, the Trump Organization, and a top executive, Allen Weisselberg, could come as soon as this week in Manhattan.
content: Lawyers for Donald J. Trump’s family business mounted a last-ditch effort on Monday to fend off criminal charges against the company, meeting with Manhattan prosecutors investigating whether it had awarded valuable benefits to a top executive without paying taxes, according to people with knowledge of the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: New York City Braces for Heat and Humidity
description: The steamy weather, with a heat index above 100, is  expected until Thursday, and the city opens centers where people can keep cool.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Inside China’s takeover of Hong Kong.
content: A year ago, a national security law unleashed a stampede of actions to bring Hong Kong into political lock step with the Chinese Communist Party: arresting activists, seizing assets, firing government workers, detaining newspaper editors and rewriting school curriculums.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Violinist Apologizes for ‘Culturally Insensitive’ Remarks About Asians
description: Pinchas Zukerman was criticized for invoking ugly stereotypes about Asians during a master class at Juilliard, which called his remarks offensive.
content: A master class by the renowned violinist Pinchas Zukerman was supposed to be the highlight of a recent virtual symposium hosted by the Juilliard School.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: A Mental Health Crisis Flares Among Young Children
description: The number of children under 13 who need urgent mental health care has been on the rise.
content: When Marie, 11, called a suicide prevention hotline in October, nobody saw it coming. Not even Marie herself, who had been bottling up feelings of loneliness and sadness for months without telling anyone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli, Carl Zimmer and Rebecca Robbins
title: Three Studies, One Result: Vaccines Point the Way Out of the Pandemic
description: New scientific research underscores the effectiveness of vaccines and their versatility in the fight against the coronavirus.
content: Three scientific studies released on Monday offered fresh evidence that widely used vaccines will continue to protect people against the coronavirus for long periods, possibly for years, and can be adapted to fortify the immune system still further if needed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mychal Denzel Smith
title: A Black Scholar’s Path From Drug Dealing to ‘30 Under 30’
description: In “Miseducated,” Brandon P. Fleming recounts a childhood of abuse, neglect and crime, and how it led him to Harvard.
content: MISEDUCATED A Memoir By Brandon P. Fleming
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz and Jesus Jiménez
title: Danny Makes Landfall Over South Carolina and Weakens Into Tropical Depression
description: Short-lived as a tropical storm, Danny is the fourth named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season.
content: The season’s fourth tropical storm, named Danny, made landfall on Monday evening over South Carolina, and then weakened into a tropical depression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Can Biden Get a Coal-State Democrat on Board With His Climate Agenda?
description: Ultimately, what Democrats are able to pass will depend on Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia.
content: A heat wave is engulfing much of the United States this week, and temperatures across the West have soared past 100 degrees Fahrenheit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisa Gabbert
title: For June Jordan and Muriel Rukeyser, the Arc of Moral Verse Bent Toward Justice
description: In her latest On Poetry column, Elisa Gabbert considers posthumous career retrospectives from two writers known for their politics.
content: What is poetry for? It might be the overwhelming question of poetry, to borrow Prufrock’s turn of phrase. What does it do, why does it matter, how can it matter, what is it for? Because reading a poem is less fun for most people than watching a movie or listening to music, it seems to need to justify itself as an art form, to offer some cultural use value above and beyond pleasure. Hence the enduring popularity of “I, too, dislike it” and “Poetry makes nothing happen” in essays on the uselessness, the hatred of poetry — suggesting that these lines, at least out of context, do have some use value.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: Novak Djokovic Aims to Win at Wimbledon, and His Side Hustle
description: The Professional Tennis Players Association, off to a slow start since it was first announced in 2020, has at times been a distraction for the world’s best men’s player.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — Novak Djokovic has the opportunity to make history many times over at the All-England Club in the coming two weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen
title: Banks will boost payouts to shareholders after the Fed’s all-clear.
description: Morgan Stanley and Wells Fargo said they would double their dividends. Other major banks offered more modest increases.
content: The country’s biggest banks are ready to put more money in their shareholders’ pockets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheila Kaplan
title: Juul to Pay $40 Million to Settle N.C. Vaping Case
description: The settlement is the first in a stream of lawsuits against the company, which has been accused of deceptive marketing practices that contributed to a wave of nicotine addiction in teenagers.
content: Juul Labs has agreed to pay North Carolina $40 million to settle the first of a spate of lawsuits brought by states and localities claiming the e-cigarette company’s marketing practices fueled widespread addiction to nicotine among young people and created a new public health problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: A new mortgage rule aims to speed modifications and slow foreclosures.
description: The new rule comes as around 3 percent of residential mortgage borrowers are now at least four months in arrears — the point at which most foreclosure processes are allowed to begin.
content: Federal officials on Monday finalized a rule intended to slow down what they fear will be a looming wave of pandemic-related foreclosures by making it easier for lenders to modify borrowers’ loan terms and by adding additional hurdles before lenders can seize homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh and Simon Marks
title: Ethiopian Forces Retreat in Tigray, and Rebels Enter the Capital
description: After months of civil war and government occupation, Tigrayan rebels have pushed a counterattack that quickly brought them to Mekelle’s doorstep. Times journalists are there.
content: MEKELLE, Ethiopia — In a major turn in Ethiopia’s eight-month civil war in the northern Tigray region, Tigrayan fighters began entering the regional capital Monday night after Ethiopian government troops retreated from the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Pride Parties and Protests Bring Excitement Back to N.Y.C. Streets
description: After a more cautious Pride last year, many New Yorkers were eager to be together again: “Bro, the energy is amazing.”
content: New York’s Pride celebrations and protests came back with a vengeance over the weekend, after a muted celebration last year because of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bradley Secker
title: Inside a Turkish Camel-Wrestling Festival
description: Held annually on the country’s Aegean coast, the Selcuk camel-wrestling festival is part of a nomadic legacy rooted in ancient Turkic tribes.
content: The arena was filled with raucous spectators who, in tiered seating, surrounded the wrestling pit below. Camels were paraded in and out of the ring, dolled up in their best regalia, their elaborate saddles noting their names, origins and their trainers or owners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: The U.S. carried out airstrikes in Iraq and Syria.
description: The United States carried out airstrikes early Monday morning in Iraq and Syria against two Iranian-backed militias that the Pentagon said had conducted drone strikes against American personnel in Iraq in recent weeks, the Defense Department said.
content: The United States carried out airstrikes early Monday morning in Iraq and Syria against two Iranian-backed militias that the Pentagon said had conducted drone strikes against American personnel in Iraq in recent weeks, the Defense Department said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: John Clem Clarke, a Pop Art Perennial in SoHo, Dies at 83
description: He bought a loft in that Manhattan neighborhood and helped form its art scene in the 1970s, then remained even as the area’s bohemian character vanished.
content: John Clem Clarke, a young star during the glory days of the SoHo art scene in the 1960s and ’70s and an early practitioner of Pop Art who went on to keep that aesthetic movement and his Manhattan neighborhood’s bohemian spirit alive into the 21st century, died on June 5 at a nursing home in Keizer, Ore. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: The Downside of Smoothies
description: “Just because there’s a leafy green in it doesn’t make it low-calorie.”
content: A: It’s very likely that you are getting more calories and sugar when you drink a smoothie than when eating whole fruits or vegetables, said Sarah B. Krieger, a registered and licensed dietitian nutritionist who spoke for the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics, a professional trade group. Smoothies enjoy a “health halo” that can be misleading, “but the bottom line is quantity, and people are often consuming a 20- or 24-fluid-ounce smoothie. That’s a lot.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: The Largest Comet Ever Found Is Making Its Move Into a Sky Near You
description: By 2031, you may be able to spot the icy object in night skies with a good telescope.
content: Astronomers spy rocky and icy wanderers of all shapes and sizes zipping past Earth all the time. But earlier this month, they were flabbergasted when they caught sight of the largest comet they’d ever seen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Catholic Church in Poland Discloses Hundreds of Sexual Abuse Accusations
description: Church authorities said they had received 368 reports of the sexual abuse, and almost half involved children under 15.
content: WARSAW — Poland’s Catholic Church, assailed by accusations that it for years ignored the sexual abuse of minors by clergy members, on Monday acknowledged that from July 2018 through the end of last year, it had received complaints of abuse against 368 boys and girls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: Reliving a Year of Death, as Havoc Reigned in the White House
description: In “Nightmare Scenario,” the Washington Post journalists Yasmeen Abutaleb and Damian Paletta retrace the Trump administration’s response to Covid from January 2020 to January 2021.
content: One of the most striking things about “Nightmare Scenario,” a new book about the Trump administration’s shambolic response to Covid-19, is how the narrative seems to run on two tracks. One follows the chaotic story of the White House and the government agencies, with staffers running around, ostensibly trying to address a deadly pandemic while also trying to please President Trump; the other follows the inexorable advance of the novel coronavirus itself, as it made its way through the American population.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: At Nobu Malibu, Dream Time With the Famous and Almost Famous
description: It’s a vibe, for sure, but the fish is pristine and the yuzu sparkles at the beachside outpost of Nobu Matsuhisa’s global culinary empire.
content: MALIBU, Calif. — Look, but don’t make it obvious. Is that Bella Hadid? Or, is that a person who’s worked extremely hard to make herself look like Bella Hadid?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins and Ashley Wong
title: Police Officers Will ‘Flood’ Times Square After Another Bystander Is Shot
description: The second shooting in the tourist destination in two months came as New York City is emerging from the pandemic and confronting a wave of gun violence.
content: Dozens of additional police officers, some working undercover, will be dispatched to Times Square, Mayor Bill de Blasio said Monday, a day after a tourist was struck by a stray bullet in broad daylight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Eric Bolling, a Trump ally, is set to host a new cable show on Newsmax.
description: “Like myself, Newsmax is concerned with the direction that Big Tech and Big Corporate Media have taken journalism and our nation,” Mr. Bolling said in a statement.
content: Eric Bolling, a pro-Trump pundit and former Fox News host, is set to return to live television next month on Newsmax, the right wing-leaning channel owned by Christopher Ruddy, a friend of former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Red America’s Covid Problem
description: Cases are rising, because of the Delta variant.
content: There was a strange Covid-19 pattern in the U.S. for much of this spring. The virus was not spreading any faster in communities with low vaccination rates than in those with high vaccination rates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Athing Mu easily wins the 800-meter race.
description: Athing Mu, a middle distance prodigy who just turned 19, ran away from the field to easily win the women’s 800 meter race in 1:56.07, the second fastest time ever run by an American, and the fastest run by anyone this year.
content: Athing Mu, a middle distance prodigy who just turned 19, ran away from the field to easily win the women’s 800 meter race in 1:56.07, the second fastest time ever run by an American, and the fastest run by anyone this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: The Supreme Court won’t hear a case challenging transgender bathroom rights.
description: An appeals court had ruled that a Virginia school board’s policy barring a transgender boy from using the boys’ bathroom was unlawful.
content: The Supreme Court turned down a request from a Virginia school board to reinstate its policy barring a transgender boy from using the boys’ bathroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Peering Under Vermeers Without Peeling Off the Paint
description: High-tech scanning techniques used by geologists, planetary scientists, drug companies and the military are revealing secrets of how artists created their masterpieces.
content: WASHINGTON — Here is a question that art experts at the National Gallery of Art are trying to tackle: Are a couple of paintings in the museum’s collection that are credited to Johannes Vermeer actually the work of Vermeer, the 17th-century Dutch artist noted for his detailed, realistic portrayals of middle-class life?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: ‘Great Entertainment’: Frances Tiafoe Upsets Stefanos Tsitsipas at Wimbledon
description: The unseeded American beat the French Open finalist in straight sets, and talked with a fellow first-round winner, Sloane Stephens, about the power of positive thinking.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — Frances Tiafoe was the underdog going into his first round match at Wimbledon on Monday afternoon against Stefanos Tsitsipas of Greece, the third seed and a recent French Open finalist. But on a rainy day at Wimbledon, the unseeded 23-year-old American shone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greg Bensinger
title: A Final Word Before Mr. Bezos Blasts Off
description: Mr. Bezos has a complicated legacy of towering ambition, extraordinary success, unimaginable personal wealth and a scorched earth business approach.
content: In over a decade in which I’ve covered Amazon, one conversation stands out as neatly summarizing the ethos of the e-commerce giant under Jeff Bezos, who will step aside as chief executive next month. An Amazon executive was confronting his new role as a buyer of large appliances, like dishwashers, after several years as a book buyer. “We had beaten publishers into submission,” the executive said, noting giddily that when “Amazon asked for a nickel, publishers know to give a dime.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Review: Martha Washington, Hilariously Haunted by Her Slaves
description: James Ijames’s amusingly cynical and eclectic new play, “The Most Spectacularly Lamentable Trial of Miz Martha Washington,” is at the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival through July 30.
content: On an evening train back from the Hudson Valley last weekend, I overheard two drunken friends — one white, one Indian American — having a loud, expletive-ridden debate two rows behind me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Biden and his aides spent the weekend working to get the infrastructure deal back on track.
description: A fragile bipartisan infrastructure deal appeared to be moving forward once again on Sunday, as moderate Republicans said they had been reassured that President Biden would not hold it hostage while Democrats simultaneously work on a larger, partisan economic package.
content: A fragile bipartisan infrastructure deal appeared to be moving forward once again on Sunday, as moderate Republicans said they had been reassured that President Biden would not hold it hostage while Democrats simultaneously work on a larger, partisan economic package.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: The rising death toll in a Miami building collapse.
content: Four days after a residential building north of Miami Beach partially collapsed, rescuers searching around the clock have found only a handful of bodies and scattered human remains amid the wreckage. The death toll has risen to nine, and more than 150 people are still missing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni and Andrew Ross Sorkin
title: The Dramatic Crash of a Buzzy Cryptocurrency Raises Eyebrows
description: Just last month, the ICP crypto token, tied to a project backed by prestigious venture capitalists, was worth tens of billions of dollars. Then, its value collapsed.
content: In early 2020, Dominic Williams was feted at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, as the next king of blockchain technology. Mr. Williams is the founder of the Dfinity Foundation, a Swiss nonprofit organization that started an ambitious project called the Internet Computer, backed by Andreessen Horowitz, one of the most prestigious venture capital firms in Silicon Valley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gardner
title: Teenage Ballers Can Cash in Earlier Than Ever. But at What Cost?
description: Male players as young as 16 have many options to play high-level basketball before the N.B.A. without going to college — and get paid big money to do it.
content: In February, Ramses Melendez, who goes by RJ, announced his college decision in a video posted to his social media accounts. A 4-star forward in the class of 2021, Melendez followed a typical formula for the video: a highlight reel and then a jersey reveal. He strayed from the script for a moment, though, when he acknowledged in a voice-over that “it wasn’t easy to make this decision.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Young adults are avoiding shots, threatening the U.S. recovery.
content: As the U.S. vaccination campaign loses steam, it’s increasingly clear that skeptical young adults are one of the biggest barriers to mass immunity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Guy Fieri Has a Reminder for America
description: The celebrity chef dishes on restaurant reopenings, delivery apps and his $80 million Food Network deal.
content: Guy Fieri recently inked an $80 million deal with the Food Network, making him the highest-paid chef on cable TV. He did this on the heels of a brutal year for the restaurant industry, which, according to the National Restaurant Association, has lost approximately $290 billion since the start of the Covid-19 pandemic and seen insufficient relief from the federal government. While the airline industry received a big bailout in March 2020, as well as additional payroll support through the pandemic, it took almost a full year for Congress to earmark a grant program for American restaurants. Fieri’s take on why they got so little so late: It’s about “voice, power and money.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: The New Racism Won’t Solve the Old Racism
description: Discrimination in the service of equality is exactly as Orwellian as it sounds.
content: Last month, Lori Lightfoot announced that, for her second anniversary as Chicago’s first openly gay, Black female mayor, she would give one-on-one interviews only to “POC reporters,” referring to “people of color,” on the grounds that she wanted to push for equity in the composition of the overwhelmingly white City Hall press corps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Gilles Sabrié
title: At This Instagram Hot Spot, All the World’s a Stage (and the Buffalo’s a Prop)
description: Photographers are flocking to a rural county in southeastern China for its quaint scenes of farmers and fishermen — made to order.
content: The morning mist was still thick between the banyan trees when the farmer appeared in the clearing, an ax slung over his shoulder as he led a water buffalo on a rope leash. In the slanting sunlight, unhurried and companionable, the two picked their way through the undergrowth, a vision of the rural idyll.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Olivia Rodrigo’s ‘Sour’ Returns to No. 1, Four Weeks Later
description: The Disney star’s debut album circles back to the top of the Billboard 200 with the equivalent of 105,000 sales in the United States.
content: Three weeks ago, a vinyl bonanza from Taylor Swift blocked Olivia Rodrigo from enjoying a second run at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, but now the teenage newcomer is back on top.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: Iraq Is Caught in the Middle as U.S. and Iran Spar on Its Soil
description: Baghdad condemned American airstrikes on Iranian-controlled militias that have been harrying U.S. operations in Iraq, fearing an escalation.
content: American airstrikes against two Iranian-backed militias on Monday were just the latest skirmish in a conflict between the United States and Iran that is playing out on Iraqi soil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: California bans state-funded travel to 5 states over anti-L.G.B.T.Q. laws.
description: Attorney General Rob Bonta added Arkansas, Florida, Montana, North Dakota and West Virginia to a list that now includes 17 states in total.
content: California will ban state-funded travel to Arkansas, Florida, Montana, North Dakota and West Virginia in response to anti-L.G.B.T.Q. legislation in those places, officials announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Kaplan
title: High Lumber Prices Add Urgency to a Decades-Old Trade Fight
description: Forced to pay more for wood, home builders want the Biden administration to settle a long-running dispute over Canadian imports. It won’t be easy.
content: WASHINGTON — A trade dispute over Canadian lumber that began when Ronald Reagan was president has become a political problem for President Biden, with home builders and members of Congress urging the administration to try to strike a deal that could help bring down the cost of critical building materials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: The head of H.H.S. says care of migrant children is improving, but urges Congress to act.
description: Xavier Becerra urged Congress to overhaul the nation’s immigration system after visiting an emergency shelter for migrant children.
content: Xavier Becerra, the secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services, pressed Congress on Monday to overhaul the nation’s immigration system after he visited an emergency shelter for migrant children on the Fort Bliss military base near El Paso.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenée Desmond-Harris
title: Race Manners: Which Black People Should I Believe?
description: White people are often admonished to defer to Black people on issues of race and racism. But Black people don't hold monolithic opinions. What to do?
content: One of the most common pieces of advice I’ve heard given to aspiring white allies is to seek out more Black opinions. This advice is often coupled with a further admonition to suspend one’s own judgment and simply defer to Black people on matters of race and racism. However, Black Americans are a diverse group with a wide range of opinions on matters related to race and racism. As a result I have seen this advice result in paralysis of judgment and also the elevation of some bad ideas that come from the “right” people. If we asked Kimberlé Crenshaw, Adolph Reed, John McWhorter, Angela Davis and Tim Scott all to weigh in on “defund the police,” we’d get five different answers. What advice do you have for prospective and aspiring white allies about evaluating media from diverse sources and ultimately drawing their own conclusions?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Greece and Turkey, Together on One Menu at Iris
description: The chef John Fraser’s latest Manhattan restaurant breaks the unwritten rule that Aegean cooking has to be predictable.
content: It has not been hard to find Greek food of very high quality in Midtown Manhattan since at least the 1990s, when Estiatorio Milos dropped anchor. What was much harder to find, whether at Milos or at the other restaurants that followed it, was food that would surprise you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: A top Fed official says digital currency may be the money equivalent of parachute pants.
description: Comparing central bank digital currencies to fads, the Fed’s vice chair for supervision said the case for a digital dollar must clear a “high bar.”
content: Randal K. Quarles, the Federal Reserve’s vice chair for supervision, suggested on Monday that the global rush to research and develop central bank digital currencies — often called C.B.D.C.s — reminds him of another four-letter abbreviation. Fear of missing out, or, as it is better known, FOMO.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: College, or Cash In? Some N.B.A. Hopefuls Face a Crossroads at 16.
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 28, 2021.
content: “The money was nice, but it wasn’t the most important factor in my decision. I want my next step to get me ready to play in the N.B.A. I asked myself: What’s the best way to get there?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: U.N. Report Calls for Sweeping Action to Root Out Racism
description: The report draws on evidence from 60 countries and urges nations to take action to root out systemic racism against people of African descent.
content: GENEVA — The United Nations human rights chief urged nations to take action to root out systemic racism against people of African descent on Monday, as she released a report calling for measures to dismantle discrimination and for sweeping changes to policing, as well as reparations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Noah Lyles wins again. Erriyon Knighton wasn’t far behind.
description: Noah Lyles has almost never lost in the 200 meter race. But one of those losses was at the 2016 United States Olympic trials, when he took fourth place.
content: Noah Lyles has almost never lost in the 200 meter race. But one of those losses was at the 2016 United States Olympic trials, when he took fourth place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Mixing Pfizer and AstraZeneca vaccines provides strong protection, according to a preliminary study.
description: Administering a first dose of one vaccine and a second dose of the other, in either order, is likely to provide potent protection, the researchers said.
content: Early results from a British vaccine study suggest that mixing different brands of vaccines can provoke a protective immune response against Covid-19. In the trial, volunteers produced high levels of antibodies and immune cells after getting one dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine and one dose of the AstraZeneca-Oxford shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron E. Carroll
title: Vaccine Mandates Are Coming. Good.
description: The United States has always needed mandates to overcome serious diseases
content: It would be nice if the United States could reach herd immunity with just vaccination incentives like tickets to ballgames and free beer. Americans don’t like to be told what to do, and public officials would almost always rather hand out cash than have to punish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: After Bodies Are Found, Some Say Canada Day Is Nothing to Celebrate
description: Heeding calls from Indigenous people, some places have canceled plans to mark the holiday, after hundreds of children’s remains were discovered at former boarding schools for Indigenous children.
content: OTTAWA — After the discovery of hundreds of bodies in unmarked graves at former schools for Indigenous children, communities across Canada are canceling or altering plans to celebrate a patriotic holiday on Thursday, increasing the pressure on Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to call off national celebrations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Quentin Tarantino Turns His Most Recent Movie Into a Pulpy Page-Turner
description: The novel “Once Upon a Time in Hollywood” tells some of the same story, but also departs from the movie in ways small and large.
content: Quentin Tarantino’s first novel is, to borrow a phrase from his oeuvre, a tasty beverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Review: At Caramoor, a Concert Signals Return and Remembrance
description: The performance, by the Orchestra of St. Luke’s, felt like normal again, while the music looked back on a year of upheaval.
content: KATONAH, N.Y. — Before a concert by the Orchestra of St. Luke’s on a steamy Sunday afternoon here at the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts, a jubilant James Roe, the ensemble’s executive director, told the audience that these musicians had not presented a live, in-person performance in 472 days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Honk if Helen Mirren and Vin Diesel Should Have Kissed in ‘F9’
description: The Oscar winner’s cameo involves a car chase and some crackling chemistry. But could things turn romantic? We put the question to Mirren herself.
content: Fire up the petitions. Notify the lobbyists. When the 10th “Fast and Furious” film is made, I have a suggestion that is really more of a demand: Vin Diesel and Helen Mirren must kiss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: Democrats are divided over how to expand Medicaid in 12 states.
description: Some Democrats are eager to build on their Affordable Care Act victories in the Supreme Court by filling a gaping hole created along the way: the lack of Medicaid coverage for millions of low-income Americans in 12 states.
content: Some Democrats are eager to build on their Affordable Care Act victories in the Supreme Court by filling a gaping hole created along the way: the lack of Medicaid coverage for millions of low-income Americans in 12 states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Porter
title: Black Workers Stopped Making Progress on Pay. Is It Racism?
description: Economists are grappling with how much to blame bias or a changing economy for the widening wage gap over the last 40 years.
content: William Spriggs, a professor at Howard University, wrote an open letter last year to his fellow economists. Reacting to the police killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis, he began the letter with a question: “Is now a teachable moment for economists?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Shawarma, Shawarma, Shawarma!
description: Whether made in a rotisserie or a standard oven, the results are thrilling every time.
content: Good morning. Air fryers, Instant Pots, sous vide machines, I’ve tried them all. With the exception of the air fryer, which I think is just a big toaster oven with a fan in it, I’m agnostic about their worth. If you use them, great. But I’ve seen a lot of kitchens where they sit, dusty and unused, in a cabinet alongside the pasta machine. When it comes to gadgets, I’m happy with a food processor, a stand mixer, my stove.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Slagle
title: Ditch Marinating for Delicious (and Faster) Summer Grilling
description: Quickly cook main ingredients over direct heat, then flavor them with bright, fresh seasonings.
content: Fire is a mighty ingredient all on its own, adding an alluring smokiness to meat, seafood, cheese and vegetables. So skip the marinade: Grill your ingredients with only oil and salt, and over unrelenting direct heat for a crisp char. Then season them hot off the grill. This style of cooking takes little time and less planning — and can simplify and shake up dinnertime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Elian Peltier
title: Fire Near London Train Station Closes Roads and Prompts Evacuations
description: The fire near the Elephant and Castle station took two hours to get under control. Officials say it was not related to terrorism.
content: LONDON — A huge fire broke out near a major train station in London on Monday, sending a fireball into the street and vast plumes of smoke over parts of the city. About 100 firefighters fought for two hours to bring the blaze under control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Despite Slips, Biles Wins at U.S. Trials and Will Lead Olympic Team
description: Sunisa Lee, Jordan Chiles and Grace McCallum will join her on the squad for the team event. Jade Carey and MyKayla Skinner qualified as individual competitors.
content: ST. LOUIS — On her way to making her second Olympic team, Simone Biles ran into doubts. Sometime during Night 2 of U.S. Olympic gymnastics trials on Sunday, they found a way into her head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Cole Hocker outkicks Matthew Centrowitz in the 1500-meters.
description: Through three rounds of racing at the trials, Matthew Centrowitz, the reigning Olympic champion in the men’s 1,500 meters, made a habit of pointing to the track whenever he was introduced to the crowd, as if to say: I own this place.
content: Through three rounds of racing at the trials, Matthew Centrowitz, the reigning Olympic champion in the men’s 1,500 meters, made a habit of pointing to the track whenever he was introduced to the crowd, as if to say: I own this place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith, Giulia Heyward and Sophie Kasakove
title: Why Young Adults Are Among the Biggest Barriers to Mass Immunity
description: Many young adults are forgoing Covid vaccines for a complex mix of reasons. Health officials are racing to find ways to change their minds.
content: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Bridget Burke, 22, a college student in Michigan, said she was unsettled by rumors that Covid-19 vaccines could affect her reproductive health. Bryson Hardy, 19, a fiber optic cable splicer from Georgia, said he was not worried about contracting the virus and had no plans to get vaccinated. And Cinda Heard, 27, an in-home health care assistant in Missouri, said she feared potential side effects from the vaccine and got a shot only because her employer required it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Cocktail Bites With a European Twist
description: Cheesy gratins are the latest in Savorly’s line of frozen hors d’oeuvres.
content: The Brooklyn company Savorly’s line of frozen hors d’oeuvres, created in Belgium and France, can be quickly heated in the oven or air fryer for an array of colorful and tasty puff pastry mini-pies, mini-tarts and cocktail bites. They’re mostly filled with vegetable mixtures, and sometimes with cheese, but no meat or seafood. Newest are the mini gratins: cauliflower and broccoli, and, my favorite, potato and cheese. These, served two or three per person, make for excellent sides with a steak or fish off the grill. There are six to 20 pieces per box.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: College Players May Make Money Off Their Fame, Powerful N.C.A.A. Panel Recommends
description: Pressured by a wave of state laws taking effect on July 1, the college sports industry is on the verge of letting players profit off their names, images and likenesses.
content: A powerful group of college sports leaders recommended Monday that student-athletes be allowed for the first time to earn money from autograph signings, personal appearances, endorsements and their social media platforms, which would be a groundbreaking shift that could see players earn millions of dollars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins
title: A third dose of the AstraZeneca vaccine is found to boost immune response.
description: A third shot of the vaccine lifted immune response in volunteers who had already received two.
content: A third dose of the Covid-19 vaccine developed by AstraZeneca and the University of Oxford generated a strong immune response in clinical trial volunteers, Oxford researchers reported on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Air Pollution’s Invisible Toll on Your Health
description: Children, pregnant women, the elderly and those with pre-existing heart or lung disease are the most vulnerable.
content: President Biden’s proposed infrastructure plan calling for huge investments in clean energy, public transportation and electric vehicles would do a lot more than slow the rate of devastating climate change. It would also protect the health of every American, especially young children and older adults, by reducing the harmful effects of the invisible air pollutants inhaled year after year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: Lawmakers Sue N.Y.P.D., Saying They Were Beaten With Bicycles at Protest
description: State Senator Zellnor Myrie and Assemblywoman Diana Richardson say they were assaulted and pepper-sprayed by the police during last year’s Black Lives Matter protests.
content: Two New York lawmakers who said they were surrounded, beaten with bicycles and pepper-sprayed by the police during a Black Lives Matter protest in Brooklyn last year filed a federal civil-rights lawsuit against the city on Monday, adding to the blizzard of litigation over the Police Department’s conduct during the protests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Grilling Tools
description: If you’re planning to do some grilling this summer, you’ll need the right tools. Here are the basics.
content: With the loosening of pandemic-related restrictions, many Americans will gather around an outdoor grill this weekend to celebrate the Fourth of July, deploying an arsenal of grilling tools to barbecue burgers, steaks and vegetables.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Skolnick
title: He Felt Like Running: 100 Days, 100 Ironman-Length Triathlons
description: James Lawrence completed 100 Ironman-distance races in 100 days. He brought a whole community — and a nonprofit that has come under scrutiny — along with him.
content: LINDON, Utah — James Lawrence slipped into a public pool in the Rocky Mountains before dawn this month, just as he had for the past 98 days. He was dressed in a sleeveless wet suit, a swim cap and tinted goggles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan B. Garland
title: A Woman’s Guide to Making the Most of Social Security
description: Women tend to live longer than men, so they need as much retirement income as possible. Whether you’re 30 or 60, here’s what you need to know.
content: As a single woman with no children, Karen Callahan is putting together the financial pieces that will protect her for a potentially long life on her own. A large piece of her puzzle: getting as much Social Security income as she can.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Dijon or Nothing
description: A new book celebrates Burgundian mustard, with recipes.
content: That July Fourth hot dog will probably be slathered with everyday yellow, but for more refined preparations, it’s Dijon that’s in demand. The city in France’s Burgundy region south of Paris, the center of French mustard production today, is just one stop on the journey that mustard has taken over 5,000 years, becoming a favorite condiment worldwide. This lively book traces the history, focusing on France and notably on Maison Fallot, a traditional Burgundian producer. There are also recipes for 40 dishes, many of them complex creations like Daniel Boulud’s Chaud-Froid of Free-Range Poularde that consists of nine separate recipes, not including plating. Others are appealingly simple, including pork tenderloin with Dijon mustard sauce from Christophe Muller of the Paul Bocuse flagship restaurant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Dear Class of 2021: Don’t Do Your Homework. Live Your Life.
description: Kara Swisher with a lesson for young people on the value of risk-taking and digital responsibility.
content: This year, I was asked to give a commencement address at a school I attended from kindergarten through fifth grade. Here is an edited version of my remarks:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Gin from Cachaça Country
description: Amázzoni makes use of the Brazil nut and cocoa in its London dry-style spirit.
content: Gin, made around the world, comes in two basic styles: austere, juniper-forward London dry, and a more aromatic herbal or floral version. For a martini and perhaps even with tonic, it’s the London dry you’ll want and, more specifically, this alluringly subtle Brazilian gin, Amázzoni, newly available in the United States. It leans on botanicals like Brazil nut, Victoria regia (a type of water lily) and cocoa. The distillery is on an 18th century coffee farm in the Paraíba Valley northwest of Rio de Janeiro. The gin is excellent on the rocks, perhaps with a few açai berries added for that Amazonian garnish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Gunfire in Times Square on a Weekend Afternoon Leaves a Man Wounded
description: The man, who was struck once in the back by a stray bullet, was listed in stable condition at Bellevue Hospital, the police said.
content: A 21-year-old man was shot once in the back on Sunday afternoon in Times Square in a brazen act of violence in one of the city’s best known tourist destinations, according to a New York City Police Department spokesman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: How a Buzzy Cryptocurrency Fizzled
description: The ICP crypto token was worth billions. Until it wasn’t.
content: The “Internet Computer” is an ambitious crypto project by the Dfinity Foundation, a Swiss nonprofit organization with big Silicon Valley backers like Andreessen Horowitz. Last month, it was the darling of the crypto world when it held a bonanza of an initial coin offering, valuing its token, known as ICP, at tens of billions of dollars in market cap. It’s a different story now, after ICP has lost more than 90 percent of its value.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Conway
title: Escapist, Easygoing Pieces for Unstructured Days
description: Attersee, a new line of breezy clothing and accessories, was partly inspired by Gustav Klimt’s summer trips to the foothills of the Austrian Alps.
content: In the early years of the last century, when the August heat settled over the sweltering streets of Vienna, Gustav Klimt would head westward to the foothills of the Alps, where he’d paint slender birch trees and other tranquil landscapes, study his Japanese art books and swim in the clear waters of Attersee, one of Austria’s largest lakes. He’d paint from the lake, too, often piloting a small rowboat, oils and canvas in tow, out onto its mineral-blue surface. Immersed in nature, he’d exchange his city clothes for an ankle-length caftan — a free-flowing garment to match his unstructured days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei, Richard Fausset and Christina Morales
title: Rubble, Narrow Voids, Storms: The Dangerous Rescue Effort in Miami
description: The death toll rose to 11 as search-and-rescue teams continued to sort through pulverized steel and dig through concrete boulders.
content: SURFSIDE, Fla. — Atop the grim pile of detritus and broken concrete on Monday, some of the world’s most elite rescue crews tunneled and dug, sometimes with their hands, in hopes of finding hints of the living. As the afternoon dragged on, it appeared their hopes would be dashed for another day.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Body Strikes Back
description: Our immune system is restrained from attacking tumors by molecules that function as “brakes.” Releasing these brakes allows our body to powerfully combat cancer.

author: By Alexandra Eaton, Christoph Koettl, Quincy G. Ledbetter, Victoria Simpson and Aaron Byrd
title: Searching for the Lost Graves of Louisiana’s Enslaved People
description: There are thousands of enslaved people buried in Louisiana’s industrial corridor. But their locations have remained a mystery. Until now. Using historical maps and aerial photos, we can locate these possible graves.
content: There are thousands of enslaved people buried in Louisiana’s industrial corridor. But their locations have remained a mystery. Until now. Using historical maps and aerial photos, we can locate these possible graves.
